2. The Electoral College could favor the Republican Party and give Trump 270 electoral votes.
3. Biden's overall standing is around 43% approval.
4. The economy could hit a downturn before the election.
5. Biden's age could become a liability as he will be the oldest president to stand for re-election in 2024.

context: Joe Biden has, to nobody’s surprise, formally announced that he is seeking re-election. And I, for one, am dreading the year and a half of political crystal ball gazing that lies ahead of us — a discussion to which I will have little if anything to add.

One thing I may be able to contribute to, however, is the way we talk about the Biden economy. Much political discussion, it seems to me, is informed by a sense that the economy will be a major liability for Democrats — a sense that is strongly affected by out-of-date or questionable data.

Of course, a lot can change between now and November 2024. We could have a recession, maybe as the delayed effect of monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve. We might all too easily face a financial crisis this summer when, as seems likely, Republicans refuse to raise the debt ceiling — and nobody knows how that will play out politically.
Right now, however, the economy is in better shape than I suspect most pundits or even generally well-informed readers may realize.

The basic story of the Biden economy is that America has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery. This recovery was initially accompanied by distressingly high inflation; but inflation, while still high by the standards of the past few decades, has subsided substantially. The overall situation is, well, not so bad.

About jobs: Unless you’ve been getting your news from Tucker Carlson or Truth Social, you’re probably aware that the unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows. However, I keep hearing assertions that this number is misleading, because millions of Americans have dropped out of the labor force — which was true a year ago.

But it’s not true anymore. There are multiple ways to make this point, but one way is to compare where we are now with projections made just before Covid struck. In January 2020 the Congressional Budget Office projected that by the first quarter of 2023 nonfarm employment would be 154.8 million; the actual number for March was 155.6 million. As a recent report from the Council of Economic Advisers points out, labor force participation — the percentage of adults either working or actively looking for work — is also right back in line with pre-Covid projections.
In short, we really are back at full employment.

Inflation isn’t as happy a picture. If we measure inflation by the annual rate of change in consumer prices over the past six months — my current preference for trying to extract the signal from the noise — inflation was almost 10 percent in June 2022. But it’s now down to just 3.5 percent.

That’s still above the Fed’s target of 2 percent, and there’s intense debate among economists about how hard it will be to get inflation all the way down (intense because nobody really knows the answer). But maybe some perspective is in order. The current inflation rate is lower than it was at the end of Ronald Reagan’s second term.

Or consider the “misery index,” the sum of unemployment and inflation — a crude measure that nonetheless seems to do a pretty good job of predicting consumer sentiment. Using six-month inflation, that index is currently about 7, roughly the same as it was in 2017, when few people considered the economy a disaster.

But never mind these fancy statistics — don’t people perceive the economy as terrible? After all, news coverage tends to emphasize the negative: You hear a lot about soaring prices of gasoline or eggs, much less when they come back down. Even amid a vast jobs boom, consumers report having heard much more negative than positive news about employment.

Even so, do people consider the economy awful? It depends on whom you ask. The venerable Michigan Survey still shows consumer sentiment at levels heretofore associated with severe economic crises. But the also well-established Conference Board survey — which, as it happens, has a much larger sample size — tells a different story: Its “present situation” index is fairly high, roughly comparable to what it was in 2017. That is, it’s more or less in line with the misery index.

And for what it’s worth, both the strength of consumer spending, even in the relatively soft latest report on G.D.P., and the failure of the much-predicted red wave to materialize in the midterm elections look a lot more Conference Board than Michigan.

Again, a lot can happen between now and the election. But what strikes me is that consumers already expect a lot of bad news. The Conference Board expectations index is far below its “present situation” index; consumers expect 4 percent to 5 percent inflation over the next year, while financial markets expect a number more like 2 percent. If we either don’t have a recession or any recession is brief and mild, if inflation actually does come down, voters seem set to view those outcomes as a positive surprise.

Now, I’m not predicting a “morning in America”-type election; such things probably aren’t even possible in an era of intense partisanship. But the idea that the economy is going to pose a huge problem for Democrats next year isn’t backed by the available data.

question: 2. How has the job market recovered in the Biden economy?
close_book_answer: The job market has recovered in the Biden economy, but not equally for all demographics.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the unemployment rate has decreased from 7.8% in January 2009 to 3.5% in September 2021.
However, this decline has not been uniform across all demographic groups.
The employment-population ratio, which measures the proportion of the working-age population that is employed, has increased from 58.2% in January 2009 to 62.6% in September 2021.

While this is a positive development, it is important to note that the employment-population ratio for African Americans and Hispanics has only increased to 56.7% and 59.1%, respectively, in September 2021.
This suggests that there is still significant work to be done to ensure that all demographic groups benefit equally from the Biden economy..
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The unemployment rate has decreased from 7.8% in January 2009 to 3.5% in September 2021.
2. The employment-population ratio has increased from 58.2% in January 2009 to 62.6% in September 2021.
3. The employment-population ratio for African Americans and Hispanics has only increased to 56.7% and 59.1%, respectively, in September 2021.
4. There is still significant work to be done to ensure that all demographic groups benefit equally from the Biden economy.

question: 3. What is the current state of inflation in the Biden economy?
close_book_answer: Inflation in the Biden economy has been a significant concern in recent months.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased by 2.4% in 2021, which is significantly higher than the Federal Reserve's target rate of 2%.
This increase in inflation can be attributed to a variety of factors, including rising energy prices, a stronger U.S.
dollar, and supply chain disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
These factors have contributed to a decrease in the purchasing power of consumers and have made it more challenging for businesses to operate profitably.
The Federal Reserve has taken steps to address inflation by raising interest rates and implementing quantitative easing measures, but the impact of these policies on inflation remains uncertain.
Overall, inflation in the Biden economy is a significant challenge that will require continued monitoring and management to ensure long-term economic stability..

2. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased by 2.4% in 2021, which is significantly higher than the Federal Reserve's target rate of 2%.
3. Rising energy prices, a stronger U.S. dollar, and supply chain disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic have contributed to the increase in inflation.
4. The Federal Reserve has taken steps to address inflation by raising interest rates and implementing quantitative easing measures, but the impact of these policies on inflation remains uncertain.
5. Inflation in the Biden economy is a significant challenge that will require continued monitoring and management to ensure long-term economic stability.

Or consider the “misery index,” the sum of unemployment and inflation — a crude measure that nonetheless seems to do a pretty good job of predicting consumer sentiment. Using six-month inflation, that index is currently about 7, roughly the same as it was in 2017, when few people considered the economy a disaster.

But never mind these fancy statistics — don’t people perceive the economy as terrible? After all, news coverage tends to emphasize the negative: You hear a lot about soaring prices of gasoline or eggs, much less when they come back down. Even amid a vast jobs boom, consumers report having heard much more negative than positive news about employment.

Even so, do people consider the economy awful? It depends on whom you ask. The venerable Michigan Survey still shows consumer sentiment at levels heretofore associated with severe economic crises. But the also well-established Conference Board survey — which, as it happens, has a much larger sample size — tells a different story: Its “present situation” index is fairly high, roughly comparable to what it was in 2017. That is, it’s more or less in line with the misery index.

And for what it’s worth, both the strength of consumer spending, even in the relatively soft latest report on G.D.P., and the failure of the much-predicted red wave to materialize in the midterm elections look a lot more Conference Board than Michigan.

Again, a lot can happen between now and the election. But what strikes me is that consumers already expect a lot of bad news. The Conference Board expectations index is far below its “present situation” index; consumers expect 4 percent to 5 percent inflation over the next year, while financial markets expect a number more like 2 percent. If we either don’t have a recession or any recession is brief and mild, if inflation actually does come down, voters seem set to view those outcomes as a positive surprise.

Now, I’m not predicting a “morning in America”-type election; such things probably aren’t even possible in an era of intense partisanship. But the idea that the economy is going to pose a huge problem for Democrats next year isn’t backed by the available data.
question: 4. What is the current state of the labor force participation rate in the Biden economy?
close_book_answer: The labor force participation rate in the Biden economy refers to the percentage of the working-age population that is either employed or actively looking for work. The current state of the labor force participation rate has been a topic of discussion in recent months.

One claim is that the labor force participation rate has increased under the Biden economy. This is because the administration has implemented policies such as the American Rescue Plan, which has provided job training and employment opportunities for individuals who have been displaced by the pandemic. Additionally, the Jobs Guarantee Program has provided a living wage for all Americans, which has incentivized more people to enter the workforce.

Another claim is that the labor force participation rate has not changed significantly under the Biden economy. This is because the pandemic has affected different industries and sectors in different ways, and some individuals may have been displaced from their jobs, while others may have had to transition to different industries or roles.

Finally, a third claim is that the labor force participation rate has decreased under the Biden economy. This is because the pandemic has resulted in a significant loss of jobs and industries, which has affected the confidence of individuals in the job market. Additionally, the shift to remote work and the use of automation has also led to a decrease in the number of jobs available.

Overall, the current state of the labor force participation rate in the Biden economy is a complex issue that is affected by various factors such as the pandemic, the shift to remote work, and the use of automation.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The labor force participation rate has increased, decreased, or remained the same under the Biden economy?
2. The American Rescue Plan and Jobs Guarantee Program have contributed to the increase or decrease of the labor force participation rate?
3. The pandemic, shift to remote work, and use of automation have affected the labor force participation rate?
4. The current state of the labor force participation rate is a complex issue.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden has announced his re-election bid.
2. The economy is in better shape than most pundits and well-informed readers may realize.
3. The unemployment rate is at historic lows.
4. Labor force participation is back in line with pre-Covid projections.
5. Inflation is currently at 3.5%, which is lower than the end of Ronald Reagan's second term.

context: Joe Biden has, to nobody’s surprise, formally announced that he is seeking re-election. And I, for one, am dreading the year and a half of political crystal ball gazing that lies ahead of us — a discussion to which I will have little if anything to add.

One thing I may be able to contribute to, however, is the way we talk about the Biden economy. Much political discussion, it seems to me, is informed by a sense that the economy will be a major liability for Democrats — a sense that is strongly affected by out-of-date or questionable data.

Of course, a lot can change between now and November 2024. We could have a recession, maybe as the delayed effect of monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve. We might all too easily face a financial crisis this summer when, as seems likely, Republicans refuse to raise the debt ceiling — and nobody knows how that will play out politically.
Right now, however, the economy is in better shape than I suspect most pundits or even generally well-informed readers may realize.

The basic story of the Biden economy is that America has experienced a remarkably fast and essentially complete job market recovery. This recovery was initially accompanied by distressingly high inflation; but inflation, while still high by the standards of the past few decades, has subsided substantially. The overall situation is, well, not so bad.

About jobs: Unless you’ve been getting your news from Tucker Carlson or Truth Social, you’re probably aware that the unemployment rate is hovering near historic lows. However, I keep hearing assertions that this number is misleading, because millions of Americans have dropped out of the labor force — which was true a year ago.

But it’s not true anymore. There are multiple ways to make this point, but one way is to compare where we are now with projections made just before Covid struck. In January 2020 the Congressional Budget Office projected that by the first quarter of 2023 nonfarm employment would be 154.8 million; the actual number for March was 155.6 million. As a recent report from the Council of Economic Advisers points out, labor force participation — the percentage of adults either working or actively looking for work — is also right back in line with pre-Covid projections.
In short, we really are back at full employment.

Inflation isn’t as happy a picture. If we measure inflation by the annual rate of change in consumer prices over the past six months — my current preference for trying to extract the signal from the noise — inflation was almost 10 percent in June 2022. But it’s now down to just 3.5 percent.

That’s still above the Fed’s target of 2 percent, and there’s intense debate among economists about how hard it will be to get inflation all the way down (intense because nobody really knows the answer). But maybe some perspective is in order. The current inflation rate is lower than it was at the end of Ronald Reagan’s second term.

And for what it’s worth, both the strength of consumer spending, even in the relatively soft latest report on G.D.P., and the failure of the much-predicted red wave to materialize in the midterm elections look a lot more Conference Board than Michigan.

Again, a lot can happen between now and the election. But what strikes me is that consumers already expect a lot of bad news. The Conference Board expectations index is far below its “present situation” index; consumers expect 4 percent to 5 percent inflation over the next year, while financial markets expect a number more like 2 percent. If we either don’t have a recession or any recession is brief and mild, if inflation actually does come down, voters seem set to view those outcomes as a positive surprise.

Now, I’m not predicting a “morning in America”-type election; such things probably aren’t even possible in an era of intense partisanship. But the idea that the economy is going to pose a huge problem for Democrats next year isn’t backed by the available data.
question: 5. What is the current state of full employment in the Biden economy?
close_book_answer: Claim 1: The Biden economy is currently at full employment.
Claim 2: The current unemployment rate is at a historic low.
Claim 3: The Biden administration' suffering from inflationary pressures.

The Biden economy is currently at full employment. The unemployment rate is at a historic low, which indicates that there are not many people who are unemployed and looking for work. Additionally, the Biden administration is facing inflationary pressures, which means that the prices of goods and services are increasing. This is a common problem that arises when the economy is operating at full employment, as there is a shortage of workers, which leads to higher wages and increased production costs. Therefore, it can be concluded that the Biden economy is currently at full employment, and the administration is facing inflationary pressures as a result.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. The Biden economy is currently at full employment.
2. The unemployment rate is at a historic low.
3. The Biden administration is facing inflationary pressures.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden has announced his re-election bid.
2. The economy is in better shape than most pundits and well-informed readers may realize.
3. The unemployment rate is at historic lows.

5. Inflation is currently at 3.5%, which is lower than the end of Ronald Reagan's second term.

context: Joe Biden is officially running for re-election, and his candidacy will put some Democratic voters — those not only skittish about his age but also about his passion for policy — in a vise: They recognize the threat from the leading Republican candidates, but they’ve been underwhelmed by Biden, who’d be 82 at the start of a second term.

The age question is a major concern for Biden, according to political advisers I’ve spoken to recently — and according to the chatter on cable news and online. And the sense that he has underwhelmed is particularly problematic for Biden when it comes to young voters. According to an Institute of Politics at Harvard Kennedy School poll of 18-to 29-year-olds released Monday, just 36 percent of young Americans approve of Biden’s job performance. That number has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency.

Though young voters were only 17 percent of the 2020 electorate, they’ll probably be a key to another Biden win, since he won about 60 percent of the 18-to-29 vote last time around. Younger voters can also be barometers of how much a candidate’s passion factors into his appeal.

I reached out to several voting rights advocates and political organizers to discuss Biden’s bid, and the overall impression settles somewhere between cautious optimism and dampened enthusiasm not so much about Biden’s age but about how voters, including younger voters, look at his policy priorities. As Clifford Albright, a co-founder and the executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, told me, although younger voters would generally like to see younger candidates, “the age thing can be overcome if you’re talking about the right issues.”

Albright mentioned the presidential candidacies of Senator Bernie Sanders, who’s about a year older than Biden. As a contender for the Democratic nomination, he said, Sanders was held aloft by young voters because he vociferously championed issues that they cared about. They felt that he was fighting for them.

It’s on those issues where some activists seemed to think Biden had left an opening for voter disappointment. They weren’t naïve about the structural obstacles in the way Congress operates that made legislative progress difficult, if not impossible, but they simply didn’t believe that Biden went down fighting on some of the initiatives that younger Democratic voters cared about most.
One that sticks in their craws, undoubtedly because they deal with voting rights, was a sense that Biden didn’t fight hard enough for the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

Nse Ufot, the founder of the New South Super PAC, chastised Biden for speaking about the voting rights bill at the Atlanta University Center — a consortium of four historically Black colleges and universities, in a state where both senators were already committed to voting for the law — ahead of a push to the pass the bill, knowing there weren’t enough votes to pass it. Biden “should have been in West Virginia,” said Ufot, and “should have been in Phoenix, Ariz., because those are the people who need to hear it.”

She said it seemed almost like a coach coming to the sideline to console a team in defeat even though there was still time left on the clock and the game was still being played. It just didn’t feel like an all-out effort to go down swinging.
Ufot, channeling the rapper Ice Cube, said of Biden, “I need you to put your back into it!”

But both Ufot and Albright considered the hesitation about Biden’s age a bit of a red herring. For them, policy and voter engagement — and the time and resources put into both — will be more determinative.

On the policy front, Albright believed that the polling for Democrats, particularly in the fall of 2022, ticked up not only because the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade but also because Biden finally took action on student loan forgiveness, the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act (with the most significant climate provisions in American history) and the passage of relatively narrow but still significant federal gun legislation. A half year later, these Democratic wins can feel like old news, but they were agenda items that Democratic voters, including young voters, cared deeply about.
So if Biden made gains on some of the issues that young voters care about, why are the activists still concerned?

Biden’s challenge when it comes to younger voters isn’t so much his age but his posture, they say. He was elected in part as an antidote to the chaos of the Donald Trump years. But, as Albright said he sees it now, “some of that stability that he offers, some of that comfort or whatever that he offers some folks, that has actually been, from our perspective, part of the problem.”

“When you’re in a moment like what we’re in,” Albright said, “you have to recognize that this is not a time for the normal, the traditional, the nostalgia or whatever and that you need something different.”
Ufot buttressed that sentiment more bluntly, saying, “People are trying to appear to be elder statesmen” when the country is, in effect, on fire.

In a certain sense, Biden’s age becomes a proxy for other dissatisfactions voters may have with him. Trump is just four years younger than Biden, but he has convinced his followers that his venom is a marker of virility.

Biden has to demonstrate more fight for more progressive policies. Even if he loses the battles, he has to show the scars. Positioning himself as the last line of defense against the return of Trump or the rise of an equally dangerous Republican isn’t sufficient.
He has to show that he is more bulldog than bulwark.

As Tram Nguyen, a co-executive director of the New Virginia Majority, put it, in the next year and a half leading up to the election, “I think you’re going to see more — at least I hope we’re going to see more — of that fight, because I think at the end of the day, voters want to vote for someone who they believe will fight for what is needed.”
question: 1. How does Joe Biden's age factor into his re-election campaign?
close_book_answer: Joe Biden's age is a significant factor in his re-election campaign.
While he is the oldest president to be elected in American history, his age has not hindered his ability to perform his duties as president.
In fact, his experience and wisdom have been valuable assets in his decision-making.
However, some critics have raised concerns about his physical stamina and mental sharpness as he approaches his 80th birthday.
These concerns have led some to question whether he has the energy and drive to continue serving as president for another term.
Additionally, his age may also play a role in his campaign strategy, with some potential voters expressing concerns about his age and fitness for office.
Overall, while his age is not the only factor in his re-election campaign, it is an important consideration that he will need to address as he seeks another term in office..
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Joe Biden's age is a significant factor in his re-election campaign.
2. While he is the oldest president to be elected in American history, his age has not hindered his ability to perform his duties as president.
3. His experience and wisdom have been valuable assets in his decision-making.
4. Some critics have raised concerns about his physical stamina and mental sharpness as he approaches his 80th birthday.
5. These concerns have led some to question whether he has the energy and drive to continue serving as president for another term.
6. His age may also play a role in his campaign strategy, with some potential voters expressing concerns about his age and fitness for office.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden is running for re-election.
2. Some Democratic voters are concerned about Biden's age and passion for policy.
3. Younger voters may be a key to Biden's re-election.
4. Biden's age is not the only concern for younger voters; policy priorities are also important.
5. Biden's policy priorities have been criticized for not being aggressive enough, particularly on issues that younger voters care about.

question: 2. What are some of the issues that younger voters care about, and how do they feel about Biden's policy priorities?
close_book_answer: As the 2024 presidential election approaches, younger voters are becoming increasingly vocal about the issues they care about and how they feel about Joe Biden's policy priorities. According to recent surveys, younger voters are most concerned about issues such as climate change, affordable healthcare, and income inequality. They also express strong support for policies that promote racial and social justice.

However, some younger voters have expressed concerns about Biden's policies, particularly his stance on criminal justice reform. While they appreciate his efforts to address the issue, they feel that he has not gone far enough and that his proposals do not go far enough to address the systemic injustices that have led to mass incarceration of people of color.

Overall, younger voters are looking for a candidate who will prioritize issues that affect their lives and who will take bold action to address them. They want a candidate who is not only committed to policy proposals but who is also willing to take on the entrenched power structures that have kept marginalized communities marginalized for too long.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Younger voters are concerned about issues such as climate change, affordable healthcare, and income inequality.
2. They express strong support for policies that promote racial and social justice.
3. Some younger voters have concerns about Biden's policies, particularly his stance on criminal justice reform.
4. Younger voters want a candidate who will prioritize issues that affect their lives and take bold action to address them.
5. They want a candidate who is committed to policy proposals and willing to take on entrenched power structures that have kept marginalized communities marginalized.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden is running for re-election.
2. Some Democratic voters are concerned about Biden's age and passion for policy.
3. Younger voters may be a key to Biden's re-election.
4. Biden's age is not the only concern for younger voters; policy priorities are also important.
5. Biden's policy priorities have been criticized for not being aggressive enough, particularly on issues that younger voters care about.

question: 3. How do political advisers and voting rights advocates view Biden's chances of winning over younger voters?
close_book_answer: Political advisers and voting rights advocates view Biden's chances of winning over younger voters as promising but not guaranteed.

On one hand, Biden's youth-oriented policies, such as his support for free community college and his plan to make student loan debt more manageable, have garnered attention from younger voters who are passionate about issues like climate change and economic inequality.
On the other hand, there is a risk that Biden's more moderate stance on issues like immigration and criminal justice reform could alienate younger voters who are more progressive on these issues.
Ultimately, it will be up to Biden to connect with younger voters and convince them that he is the best candidate to lead the country forward..

2. There is a risk that Biden's more moderate stance on issues could alienate younger voters.

That number has steadily dropped over the course of his presidency.

Though young voters were only 17 percent of the 2020 electorate, they’ll probably be a key to another Biden win, since he won about 60 percent of the 18-to-29 vote last time around. Younger voters can also be barometers of how much a candidate’s passion factors into his appeal.

I reached out to several voting rights advocates and political organizers to discuss Biden’s bid, and the overall impression settles somewhere between cautious optimism and dampened enthusiasm not so much about Biden’s age but about how voters, including younger voters, look at his policy priorities. As Clifford Albright, a co-founder and the executive director of the Black Voters Matter Fund, told me, although younger voters would generally like to see younger candidates, “the age thing can be overcome if you’re talking about the right issues.”

Albright mentioned the presidential candidacies of Senator Bernie Sanders, who’s about a year older than Biden. As a contender for the Democratic nomination, he said, Sanders was held aloft by young voters because he vociferously championed issues that they cared about. They felt that he was fighting for them.

It’s on those issues where some activists seemed to think Biden had left an opening for voter disappointment. They weren’t naïve about the structural obstacles in the way Congress operates that made legislative progress difficult, if not impossible, but they simply didn’t believe that Biden went down fighting on some of the initiatives that younger Democratic voters cared about most.
One that sticks in their craws, undoubtedly because they deal with voting rights, was a sense that Biden didn’t fight hard enough for the John Lewis Voting Rights Act.

Nse Ufot, the founder of the New South Super PAC, chastised Biden for speaking about the voting rights bill at the Atlanta University Center — a consortium of four historically Black colleges and universities, in a state where both senators were already committed to voting for the law — ahead of a push to the pass the bill, knowing there weren’t enough votes to pass it. Biden “should have been in West Virginia,” said Ufot, and “should have been in Phoenix, Ariz., because those are the people who need to hear it.”

She said it seemed almost like a coach coming to the sideline to console a team in defeat even though there was still time left on the clock and the game was still being played. It just didn’t feel like an all-out effort to go down swinging.
Ufot, channeling the rapper Ice Cube, said of Biden, “I need you to put your back into it!”

But both Ufot and Albright considered the hesitation about Biden’s age a bit of a red herring. For them, policy and voter engagement — and the time and resources put into both — will be more determinative.

On the policy front, Albright believed that the polling for Democrats, particularly in the fall of 2022, ticked up not only because the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade but also because Biden finally took action on student loan forgiveness, the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act (with the most significant climate provisions in American history) and the passage of relatively narrow but still significant federal gun legislation. A half year later, these Democratic wins can feel like old news, but they were agenda items that Democratic voters, including young voters, cared deeply about.
So if Biden made gains on some of the issues that young voters care about, why are the activists still concerned?

Biden’s challenge when it comes to younger voters isn’t so much his age but his posture, they say. He was elected in part as an antidote to the chaos of the Donald Trump years. But, as Albright said he sees it now, “some of that stability that he offers, some of that comfort or whatever that he offers some folks, that has actually been, from our perspective, part of the problem.”

“When you’re in a moment like what we’re in,” Albright said, “you have to recognize that this is not a time for the normal, the traditional, the nostalgia or whatever and that you need something different.”
Ufot buttressed that sentiment more bluntly, saying, “People are trying to appear to be elder statesmen” when the country is, in effect, on fire.

In a certain sense, Biden’s age becomes a proxy for other dissatisfactions voters may have with him. Trump is just four years younger than Biden, but he has convinced his followers that his venom is a marker of virility.

Biden has to demonstrate more fight for more progressive policies. Even if he loses the battles, he has to show the scars. Positioning himself as the last line of defense against the return of Trump or the rise of an equally dangerous Republican isn’t sufficient.
He has to show that he is more bulldog than bulwark.

As Tram Nguyen, a co-executive director of the New Virginia Majority, put it, in the next year and a half leading up to the election, “I think you’re going to see more — at least I hope we’re going to see more — of that fight, because I think at the end of the day, voters want to vote for someone who they believe will fight for what is needed.”
question: 4. What role do younger voters play in determining the outcome of the 2024 presidential election?
close_book_answer: The role of younger voters in determining the outcome of the 2024 presidential election cannot be overstated. This demographic is known for its political activism and willingness to engage with issues that matter to them. With the current generation of young people being the most diverse in American history, the youth vote will likely play a significant role in shaping the political landscape of the 2024 election.

Firstly, younger voters are expected to turn out in higher numbers in 2024 compared to previous elections. According to recent polls, millennials and Gen Z voters are more engaged and politically active than their predecessors. This trend is likely to continue, with younger voters becoming increasingly vocal about issues such as climate change, social justice, and income inequality.

Secondly, younger voters are more likely to support progressive policies and candidates. This trend is evident in the support for candidates such as Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who have mobilized young people to engage in the political process. The youth vote is also more likely to support policies such as Medicare for All, free college education, and a Green New Deal, which are gaining traction among younger voters.

Lastly, younger voters are more likely to use technology and social media to engage with political campaigns and candidates. This trend is likely to continue, with younger voters demanding more transparency and accountability from political candidates and their campaigns. This means that political campaigns will need to adapt to the changing landscape and engage with younger voters in new and innovative ways.

In conclusion, the youth vote will play a significant role in determining the outcome of the 2024 presidential election. With younger voters being more politically active, progressive in their views, and more likely to use technology, they are poised to make their voices heard in the 2024 election.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Younger voters are expected to turn out in higher numbers in 2024 compared to previous elections.
2. Younger voters are more likely to support progressive policies and candidates.
3. Younger voters are more likely to use technology and social media to engage with political campaigns and candidates.
point_form_context: 1. Joe Biden is running for re-election.
2. Some Democratic voters are concerned about Biden's age and passion for policy.
3. Younger voters may be a key to Biden's re-election.
4. Biden's age is not the only concern for younger voters; policy priorities are also important.
5. Biden's policy priorities have been criticized for not being aggressive enough, particularly on issues that younger voters care about.

context: Joe Biden is officially running for re-election, and his candidacy will put some Democratic voters — those not only skittish about his age but also about his passion for policy — in a vise: They recognize the threat from the leading Republican candidates, but they’ve been underwhelmed by Biden, who’d be 82 at the start of a second term.

question: 5. How can Biden demonstrate more fight for progressive policies to win over younger voters?
close_book_answer: To demonstrate more fight for progressive policies and win over younger voters, Biden should:

1. Emphasize the importance of climate change and commit to bold, ambitious policies to address it. Younger voters are increasingly concerned about climate change and want to see political leaders take it seriously. By proposing a comprehensive climate change plan and making it a priority, Biden can appeal to this demographic.

2. Advocate for student loan forgiveness and tuition-free public colleges. Many younger voters are burdened by student loan debt and struggling to afford higher education. By proposing policies that would make college more affordable, Biden can show that he is fighting for the future of younger generations.

3. Support policies that promote economic equality and address income inequality. Younger voters are more likely to be progressive in their political views and are more likely to support candidates who support policies that promote economic equality. By proposing policies that address income inequality, such as raising the minimum wage and implementing progressive tax policies, Biden can appeal to younger voters who are concerned about economic inequality.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Emphasize the importance of climate change and commit to bold, ambitious policies to address it.
2. Advocate for student loan forgiveness and tuition-free public colleges.
3. Support policies that promote economic equality and address income inequality.

context: As Republican candidates enter the race for their party’s 2024 presidential nomination, Times columnists, Opinion writers and others will assess their strengths and weaknesses with a scorecard. We rate the candidates on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the candidate will probably drop out before any caucus or primary voting; 10 means the candidate has a very strong chance of receiving the party’s nomination next summer. This entry assesses Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey.

Frank Bruni Medium seriously, not for his minuscule potential to be the nominee but for his somewhat greater potential to diminish Donald Trump and to scramble the overall picture. Among Trump’s challengers, he has a singular combination of meanness and keenness, and he’s not vying for veep. He won’t walk on eggshells. He’ll do some vengeful, spiteful Jersey jitterbug on them.
Jane Coaston Mildly.
Michelle Cottle As a potential president, not very. As someone who could rough up Trump for the entire field — a political picador of sorts — he has potential.
Ross Douthat Unless he invents a time dial that spins us back to 2012, the year he probably should have run for president, not seriously at all.

David French There’s a distinction between Chris Christie’s presence in the race and his candidacy. His candidacy isn’t serious. There is zero path to victory. But his presence might matter, just as it did when he demolished Marco Rubio’s candidacy in a 2016 primary debate.

Nicole Hemmer Chris Christie is a deeply unpopular politician, but he’s also a man on a mission: to take out Trump. Understood in that light, he’s worth paying attention to, if only to see which of Trump’s weaknesses he’s able to exploit.
Katherine Mangu-Ward He’s having fun with it. So should we.
Daniel McCarthy He’s not a plausible contender. But he must sense that he’s not any less plausible than the other alternatives to Donald Trump, so why not run?

Bruni He’s not fashioning himself as Trump-plus, Trump-minus or any other improved version of Trump. He’s the anti-Trump, imploring Republicans to grapple with who Trump is and how far the party has staggered from its supposed principles. That’s a noble play even if it’s a self-aggrandizing ploy.
Coaston He believes that there is a way to be a Republican that isn’t Trumpian, and he believes that Americans will respond to that version of the G.O.P.
Cottle Well, someone needs to experiment with going hard at the MAGA king. If he can muster the will, Christie has skill.

Douthat There’s a narrative in which having played a crucial role in Donald Trump’s 2016 ascent — shivving Trump’s rivals on the debate stage and then offering him an early endorsement — Christie will now play a crucial role in his downfall, by attacking Trump with the gusto he once brought to taking down Marco Rubio. But I’m not sure that Christie will even qualify for the debate stage; if he does, I suspect he’ll be strongly tempted to attack his non-Trump rivals as often as he swings at Trump; and even if he attacks Trump, I don’t think he’s particularly well positioned to prosecute the case.
French Christie is a guided missile aimed rhetorically right at Trump.

Hemmer Christie bullies well. In the 2016 primaries, he relished eviscerating Senator Rubio. He failed to do the same to Trump at the time, but seven years later, he has plenty of new material to work with.

Mangu-Ward The conventional wisdom holds that Christie can take a bite out of Trump’s support by getting in some one-liners at the debates. But that gives too much weight to the debates themselves. There is simply no zinger zingy enough to bring down Trump — or to overcome Christie’s mixed record as a smart, accomplished governor whose pragmatism too often bleeds into the appearance of opportunism or even corruption.
McCarthy He’ll make other not-Trumps seem bland by comparison. Christie’s ridicule won’t stop the ex-president but could maim anyone else unlucky enough to be its target.

Bruni Well, he’s wagering that America is better than Trump — that a critical mass of Republicans can finally grasp the Trump threat and see the Trump damage. I’m inspired by that possibility, no matter how remote.
Coaston I don’t find his vision — a particular kind of American stasis — particularly inspiring or unsettling.
Cottle Does he have one? Does it matter?
Douthat Nothing in particular, since I don’t think he’s offering one yet.

French By far the most inspiring aspect of Christie’s candidacy is his vision for a Trump-free G.O.P. By far the most unsettling is Christie’s previous sycophantic capitulation to the same man he attacks today. How much can any voter trust that Christie has learned his lesson?

Hemmer People run for president for all sorts of reasons other than to become president: to promote new policies, break glass ceilings, increase book sales. Some mix of genuine concern for the party and vengeance (Trump booted Christie as transition chair in 2016 and most likely gave him a grave case of Covid in 2020) isn’t the worst reason to run.
Mangu-Ward Christie’s vision of America seems to be one where Donald Trump is not president. For some, perhaps that is inspiring enough.
McCarthy His vision for America is New Jersey, and most Republicans, at least, find that unsettling.

Bruni By the Iowa caucuses, Trump could be under multiple indictments and in such a flamboyant mental tailspin that Republicans must listen seriously to his rivals. Are they really going to prefer DeSantis’s whine to Christie’s roar?
Coaston New Jersey normalcy.
Cottle Takes a bully to smack a bully.
Douthat Don’t want Trump? The rules are clear: Only a tristate-area Republican can defeat another tristate-area Republican.
French No one is more dangerous than a man with nothing to lose.
Hemmer You want a straight-talking, no-holds-barred candidate who will pummel your enemies but stop short of fomenting an insurrection? Christie’s your guy.
Mangu-Ward Spicy words, bland policies.
McCarthy Wouldn’t it be fun to see him debate Joe Biden?

question: 2. What is the opinion of Frank Bruni on Chris Christie's candidacy?
close_book_answer: Frank Bruni, an op-ed columnist for The New York Times, has expressed a negative opinion of Chris Christie's candidacy for the 2016 presidential election.

In a column published in August 2015, Bruni criticized Christie's leadership style, calling it "bullying" and "petty." He also questioned Christie's ability to connect with voters, citing his unpopularity in his home state of New Jersey.
Bruni has been critical of Christie's handling of the Hurricane Sandy relief effort, as well as his handling of the George Washington Bridge scandal.
Overall, Bruni sees Christie as a divisive and unappealing candidate who lacks the leadership qualities necessary to be president..

2. Bruni questioned Christie's ability to connect with voters, citing his unpopularity in his home state of New Jersey.
3. Bruni has been critical of Christie's handling of the Hurricane Sandy relief effort.
4. Bruni also questioned Christie's handling of the George Washington Bridge scandal.
5. Frank Bruni sees Chris Christie as a divisive and unappealing candidate who lacks the leadership qualities necessary to be president.

There is simply no zinger zingy enough to bring down Trump — or to overcome Christie’s mixed record as a smart, accomplished governor whose pragmatism too often bleeds into the appearance of opportunism or even corruption.
McCarthy He’ll make other not-Trumps seem bland by comparison. Christie’s ridicule won’t stop the ex-president but could maim anyone else unlucky enough to be its target.

Bruni Well, he’s wagering that America is better than Trump — that a critical mass of Republicans can finally grasp the Trump threat and see the Trump damage. I’m inspired by that possibility, no matter how remote.

Cottle Does he have one? Does it matter?

Frank Bruni Medium seriously, not for his minuscule potential to be the nominee but for his somewhat greater potential to diminish Donald Trump and to scramble the overall picture. Ross Douthat Unless he invents a time dial that spins us back to 2012, the year he probably should have run for president, not seriously at all.

David French There’s a distinction between Chris Christie’s presence in the race and his candidacy. His candidacy isn’t serious. There is zero path to victory. But his presence might matter, just as it did when he demolished Marco Rubio’s candidacy in a 2016 primary debate.

question: 4. What is Michelle Cottle's opinion on Chris Christie's candidacy?
close_book_answer: Michelle Cottle, a journalist and political analyst, has expressed a critical view of Chris Christie's candidacy.
In her opinion, Christie's presidential bid is not well-suited to the current political climate, and he lacks the charisma and appeal necessary to succeed as a candidate.
Cottle argues that Christie's past scandals, such as the Bridgegate scandal, have tarnished his image and made it difficult for him to connect with voters.
She also points out that Christie's more moderate policies, such as his support for gun control and Obamacare, may alienate some of his more conservative supporters.
Ultimately, Cottle believes that Christie's campaign is doomed to fail, and that he lacks the necessary skills and qualities to become the next president of the United States..

question: 5. What is Ross Douthat's opinion on Chris Christie's candidacy?
close_book_answer: Ross Douthat, a conservative columnist for The New York Times, has expressed a mixed opinion on Chris Christie's candidacy.
On one hand, he has praised Christie's ability to govern a blue state and his willingness to take on powerful interest groups.
On the other hand, he has criticized Christie's past political mistakes and his tendency to use aggressive rhetoric.
In a column published in January 2016, Douthat wrote that Christie's "combative, take-no-prisoners style" may be appealing to some voters, but it could also be a liability in a general election.
Ultimately, Douthat has not endorsed Christie's candidacy, but he has acknowledged the governor's strengths and weaknesses..

question: 6. What is David French's opinion on Chris Christie's candidacy?
close_book_answer: David French has been critical of Chris Christie's candidacy.
He argues that Christie's lack of a clear conservative message and his perceived moderate stance on key issues make him an unsuitable candidate for the Republican party.

French believes that Christie's past record of supporting big government policies, such as the "Bridgegate" scandal, and his support for common core education standards also raise concerns about his commitment to conservative principles.
Overall, French suggests that Christie's candidacy is a betrayal of conservative values and a threat to the future of the Republican party..

Mangu-Ward Christie’s vision of America seems to be one where Donald Trump is not president. For some, perhaps that is inspiring enough.
McCarthy His vision for America is New Jersey, and most Republicans, at least, find that unsettling.

Bruni By the Iowa caucuses, Trump could be under multiple indictments and in such a flamboyant mental tailspin that Republicans must listen seriously to his rivals. Are they really going to prefer DeSantis’s whine to Christie’s roar?
Coaston New Jersey normalcy.
Cottle Takes a bully to smack a bully.
Douthat Don’t want Trump? The rules are clear: Only a tristate-area Republican can defeat another tristate-area Republican.
French No one is more dangerous than a man with nothing to lose.
Hemmer You want a straight-talking, no-holds-barred candidate who will pummel your enemies but stop short of fomenting an insurrection? Christie’s your guy.
Mangu-Ward Spicy words, bland policies.
McCarthy Wouldn’t it be fun to see him debate Joe Biden?

context: MIAMI — There was no fanfare, no live broadcast, no backdrop of uniformed schoolchildren to cheer him on. At 11:27 p.m. on April 13, hours after the closed-door ceremony, Gov. Ron DeSantis’s office sent out an email with the subject line: “Governor DeSantis Signs Two Bills.” One was titled Causes of Action Based on Improvements to Real Property; the other was one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country, effectively banning abortion after six weeks.

Early the next morning, Mr. DeSantis left Tallahassee to resume his book tour and deliver a speech at Liberty University in Virginia, the conservative Christian bastion of anti-abortion activism. Even there, he couldn’t find the nerve to mention his Heartbeat Protection Act.

Mr. DeSantis knows that banning abortion isn’t popular. The issue has been a losing one for Republicans in races across the country since Roe v. Wade was overturned last June. And according to a 2022 poll by Florida Atlantic University, 67 percent of Florida voters want abortion to be legal in most cases and only 12 percent support an outright ban. But as the governor prepares to run for president, he needs to keep hard-right primary voters satisfied.

As I watched all this unfold, I couldn’t help noting the contrast between the governor’s seeming desire to hide the abortion bill out of sight with the way some of the most ardent supporters of the law make their position known.

The billboards were one of the first things I noticed when my family and I moved to Central Florida in 2021. We drove around the state a lot, and as we made our way through the sprawl of the Miami suburbs, across the upper reaches of the Everglades where a river of grass transitions to a sea of sugar cane, through the citrus groves of aptly named towns like Frostproof and Fruitland Park, I was struck by the number of anti-abortion billboards we passed on the roadside.

Some are simple messages meant to induce shame, with pseudoscientific statistics and cute baby pictures. Many offer a friendly face and a phone number for a religious counseling center. All are stark and jarring against the powder-blue Florida sky.

Recently, I set out on a road trip to document some of the many billboards standing in the empty parking lots of long-forgotten motels and strip clubs. I sought out the signs that loom over early morning commuters at corner gas stations and provide a little extra income for the Pentecostal churches and boarded-up restaurants that host them. Along quiet country roads, they keep the cows and crows company; on bustling, strip-mall-lined boulevards they jockey for attention with an alarming number of ads for personal injury lawyers.

Right now, a woman in Florida is about a half-hour drive, on average, from a place where she can get an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy, according to research by Caitlin Myers, an economist at Middlebury College. When the bill that Mr. DeSantis signed last week goes into effect, that drive will, for most women, take over nine hours, much of it along these very highways. It’s a long road ahead.

question: 2. How did Governor Ron DeSantis sign the two bills?
close_book_answer: Governor Ron DeSantis signed the two bills, Senate Bill 7090 and House Bill 193, into law using his executive power on May 2, 2 CFIs. The signing took place at the Benjamin School in Palm Beach Gardens, where DeSantis delivered remarks on the importance of college affordability and student loan debt relief. In his remarks, DeSantis highlighted the need for Florida to invest in its future workforce and reduce the burden of student loan debt for its residents.

DeSantis signed the bills with a pen that he had given to U.S. President Donald Trump during a visit to the White House earlier this year. The signing was attended by several students and advocates who had pushed for the bills' passage, as well as members of the Florida Legislature who had supported the measures.

The signing of the bills into law was met with praise from advocates and education officials, who saw it as a step towards making higher education more accessible and affordable for Florida residents. The bills' passage and signing marked a significant victory for the advocates who had fought for years to reduce the burden of student loan debt on Florida residents.

question: 3. Why did Governor Ron DeSantis sign the abortion bill?
close_book_answer: In January 2 I recently came across an article in The Economist that discussed the state of America’s infrastructure. The article pointed out that while America’s infrastructure is aging and in need of repair, the government has been slow to invest in it. In fact, the article stated that America spends less on infrastructure than any other G7 country.

This lack of investment has led to a backlog of maintenance and repair work that has only gotten worse over time. The article cited an estimate from the American Society of Civil Engineers that it would take $3.6 trillion to bring America’s infrastructure up to a good state of repair.

The article also discussed some of the specific problems facing America’s infrastructure, including crumbling roads and bridges, outdated electrical grids, and inadequate water and sewer systems. These problems are not just a nuisance; they can also have serious consequences, such as economic disruption and public health risks.

The article suggested that one of the reasons for the lack of investment in infrastructure is political. Some politicians are reluctant to raise taxes or borrow money to pay for infrastructure projects, while others are skeptical of government involvement in the economy.

Another factor is that infrastructure projects can be expensive and time-consuming, and they often involve complex negotiations with various stakeholders. This can make it difficult to get projects off the ground, especially in an environment where political priorities can change quickly.

Despite these challenges, the article argued that investing in infrastructure is essential for America’s long-term economic growth and competitiveness. The author cited research that showed that every dollar spent on infrastructure can generate as much as $4 in economic growth.

The article also pointed out that many of the infrastructure projects that are most in need of funding are also the ones that can have the greatest impact on communities, such as improving access to transportation and expanding broadband internet access.

In conclusion, the article highlighted the need for a comprehensive approach to infrastructure investment that takes into account the many different types of infrastructure that are needed to support a modern economy. This approach should involve a combination of public and private investment, as well as careful planning and coordination among different levels of government.

2. The government has been slow to invest in infrastructure.
3. America spends less on infrastructure than any other G7 country.
4. A lack of investment has led to a backlog of maintenance and repair work.
5. Infrastructure projects can be expensive and time-consuming, and they often involve complex negotiations with various stakeholders.

question: 4. What is the impact of the abortion bill on women in Florida?
close_book_answer: The abortion bill has significant implications for women in Florida, particularly those who are low-income or live in rural areas.
The new restrictions on abortion access may make it more difficult for these women to access safe and legal abortion services, potentially leading to increased risks to their health and well-being.
Additionally, the ban on insurance coverage for abortion may result in financial burdens for women who need to access these services, further limiting their options and autonomy.
The bill also sends a message that women's reproductive rights are not valued in Florida, which could have broader implications for gender equality and women's empowerment.
Ultimately, the abortion bill is a setback for women's rights and health in Florida and should be opposed by anyone who values gender equality and access to healthcare..

question: 5. How do the anti-abortion billboards in Florida contrast with the governor's approach to the abortion bill?
close_book_answer: The anti-abortion billboards in Florida are a stark contrast to the governor's approach to the abortion bill. While the governor supports the legislation, the billboards are a controversial and aggressive campaign to end abortion in the state. The billboards feature graphic images of aborted fetuses and a message urging Floridians to "choose life" (Baltzell, 2023). This approach is divisive and confrontational, and it is unlikely to sway people to the anti-abortion cause.

Furthermore, the billboards are misleading and do not provide a full picture of the issue at hand. They focus on the emotional and moral aspects of abortion, rather than the practical realities of the decision. The billboards do not address the complex reasons why women may choose to have an abortion, such as financial constraints or lack of support from family and friends. By only presenting one side of the issue, the billboards fail to promote meaningful dialogue and understanding.

In contrast, the governor's approach to the abortion bill is more nuanced and inclusive. The governor has stated that the legislation is aimed at protecting the health and safety of women, and he has expressed support for exceptions for rape and incest (Baltzell, 2023). This approach acknowledges the complexity of the issue and recognizes that women should have access to safe and legal abortions when necessary.

In conclusion, the anti-abortion billboards in Florida are a divisive and confrontational campaign that fails to promote meaningful dialogue and understanding. In contrast, the governor's approach to the abortion bill is more nuanced and inclusive, recognizing the complexity of the issue and supporting exceptions for rape and incest.

3. The approach is divisive and confrontational and is unlikely to sway people to the anti-abortion cause.
4. The billboards are misleading and do not provide a full picture of the issue at hand.

context: Only 47 percent of Democrats want to see Joe Biden on the ballot in 2024, according to the latest Associated Press poll. That’s not because they think he’s done a bad job in office. Democrats tend to like President Biden and continue to give him good marks on handling the economy and foreign policy.

But many Democrats, particularly younger ones, are worried that he will simply be too old to be effective in a second term, which would end when he is 86. “My problem with him running in 2024 is that he’s just so old,” one Democrat told pollsters.

That may be deeply unfair — people age at different rates — and in Mr. Biden’s case, it’s impossible to deny that politics and conspiracy theories, rather than facts, fuel at least some of the concern. But candidates shouldn’t pretend, as Mr. Biden often does, that advanced age isn’t an issue. Mr. Biden is 80 now, the oldest American to serve as president, and even supporters, including the political strategist David Axelrod, have expressed deep worries that his age will be both a political liability in 2024 and a barrier to a successful second term. If Mr. Biden runs again, as he recently said he intends to, questions will persist about his age until he does more to assure voters that he is up to the job.

Mr. Biden’s age makes him an outlier even in an era when the nation’s political leadership is getting older. The current Senate, where the average age is 63.9 years, is the second oldest since 1789. The House, where the average age is 57.5 years, is the third oldest. By comparison, the average age in the United States is 38.8 years.

Concerns about age — both in terms of fitness for office and being out of touch with the moment — are legitimate, as Mr. Biden acknowledged in an interview in February with ABC News. His standard line, repeated in that interview, is: “The only thing I can say is, ‘Watch me.’”
But Mr. Biden has given voters very few chances to do just that — to watch him — and his refusal to engage with the public regularly raises questions about his age and health.

The usual White House method of demonstrating a president’s mastery is to take tough questions in front of cameras, but Mr. Biden has not taken advantage of that opportunity, as The Times reported on Friday. He has held fewer news conferences and media interviews than most of his modern predecessors. Since 1923, only Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan took fewer questions per month from reporters, and neither represents a model of presidential openness that Mr. Biden should want to emulate. His reticence has created an opening for critics and skeptics.

The president also needs to talk about his health openly and without embarrassment, and to end the pretense that it doesn’t matter. Those who are watching him with an open mind have seen a strong performance this year. His State of the Union address on Feb. 7 shattered the Republican attempts to portray him as doddering. With a passion rarely seen at one of these speeches — let alone in his political history — Mr. Biden presented a remarkably effective defense of his presidency and gave a preview of what is likely to be an imminent re-election campaign.

The Times reported last summer that Mr. Biden’s overall energy level has declined, and he continues to stumble over words in his public appearances. But those flaws alone don’t signal a politician who is too old to run again. His first term, in fact, is already full of accomplishment: The economy has added 12.6 million jobs since he took office, inflation is cooling, and he has signed significant legislation to fight climate change, improve access to health care, and make investments in manufacturing and infrastructure. He has stood up to Russia’s destructive campaign in Ukraine, and rallied the West to Ukraine’s side.

Nonetheless, as Mr. Biden nears his actuarial life expectancy, concerns about his ability to handle the demands of campaigning and a potential second term are unlikely to disappear. Only a combination of performance and complete candor will change the minds of skeptical voters. Old age remains a sensitive topic, and many people, particularly men, are reluctant to discuss personal infirmities for fear of demonstrating weakness or being pushed aside by impatient younger generations. There is good reason for the federal government’s prohibition of age discrimination in employment — a protection that begins at age 40. Ageism is real.

That law, however, doesn’t apply to people who are running for office. Voters have every right to ask questions about the medical condition of a candidate who wants their support. In 2016 both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton gave the public very few details about their health. (Mr. Trump released a particularly preposterous doctor’s letter claiming he would be “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.”)

Mr. Biden acknowledged during the lead-up to the 2020 campaign that he was “chronologically” old but said it was up to voters to decide whether that was important. In that election, against an opponent who was only four years younger, the answer was clearly no. In November 2021, he released a medical report that said he was a “healthy, vigorous 78-year-old” and noted nothing more serious than a stiffened gait due to spinal changes and some acid reflux that caused him to cough.

His most recent health summary, released on Feb. 16, said much the same thing, describing him as a “healthy, vigorous 80-year-old male who is fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency.” But his cognitive abilities went unmentioned. That’s something he should discuss publicly and also demonstrate to the voters, who expect the president to reflect the nation’s strength.

If he runs again, Mr. Biden will need to provide explicit reassurance to voters; many of them have seen family members decline rapidly in their 80s. Americans are watching what Mr. Biden says and does, just as he has asked them to do.
question: 1. How does age impact a president's ability to effectively serve in a second term?
close_book_answer: A president's ability to effectively serve in a second term can be impacted by their age.
Younger presidents may be more energetic and capable of making quick decisions, but they may lack the experience and wisdom that comes with age.

On the other hand, older presidents may have more experience and wisdom, but they may struggle with the physical demands of the job and may be more likely to make mistakes due to a decline in cognitive function.
Additionally, the pressure of a second term can take a toll on a president's mental and physical health, which can further impact their ability to serve effectively.
Ultimately, the age of a president at the time of their second term can have a significant impact on their ability to lead and make decisions..
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. A president's age can impact their ability to serve in a second term.
2. Younger presidents may have more energy but lack experience and wisdom.
3. Older presidents may have more experience and wisdom but struggle with physical demands.
4. The pressure of a second term can impact a president's mental and physical health.
5. The age of a president at the time of their second term can significantly impact their ability to lead and make decisions.
point_form_context: 1. Only 47 percent of Democrats want to see Joe Biden on the ballot in 2024.
2. Many Democrats, particularly younger ones, are worried that he will simply be too old to be effective in a second term.
3. Mr. Biden’s age makes him an outlier even in an era when the nation’s political leadership is getting older.
4. Concerns about age — both in terms of fitness for office and being out of touch with the moment — are legitimate.
5. Mr. Biden has given voters very few chances to watch him and his refusal to engage with the public regularly raises questions about his age and health.

context: Only 47 percent of Democrats want to see Joe Biden on the ballot in 2024, according to the latest Associated Press poll. That’s not because they think he’s done a bad job in office. Democrats tend to like President Biden and continue to give him good marks on handling the economy and foreign policy.

But many Democrats, particularly younger ones, are worried that he will simply be too old to be effective in a second term, which would end when he is 86. “My problem with him running in 2024 is that he’s just so old,” one Democrat told pollsters.

That may be deeply unfair — people age at different rates — and in Mr. Biden’s case, it’s impossible to deny that politics and conspiracy theories, rather than facts, fuel at least some of the concern. But candidates shouldn’t pretend, as Mr. Biden often does, that advanced age isn’t an issue. Mr. Biden is 80 now, the oldest American to serve as president, and even supporters, including the political strategist David Axelrod, have expressed deep worries that his age will be both a political liability in 2024 and a barrier to a successful second term. If Mr. Biden runs again, as he recently said he intends to, questions will persist about his age until he does more to assure voters that he is up to the job.

Mr. Biden’s age makes him an outlier even in an era when the nation’s political leadership is getting older. The current Senate, where the average age is 63.9 years, is the second oldest since 1789. The House, where the average age is 57.5 years, is the third oldest. By comparison, the average age in the United States is 38.8 years.

Concerns about age — both in terms of fitness for office and being out of touch with the moment — are legitimate, as Mr. Biden acknowledged in an interview in February with ABC News. His standard line, repeated in that interview, is: “The only thing I can say is, ‘Watch me.’”
But Mr. Biden has given voters very few chances to do just that — to watch him — and his refusal to engage with the public regularly raises questions about his age and health.

The usual White House method of demonstrating a president’s mastery is to take tough questions in front of cameras, but Mr. Biden has not taken advantage of that opportunity, as The Times reported on Friday. He has held fewer news conferences and media interviews than most of his modern predecessors. Since 1923, only Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan took fewer questions per month from reporters, and neither represents a model of presidential openness that Mr. Biden should want to emulate. His reticence has created an opening for critics and skeptics.

The president also needs to talk about his health openly and without embarrassment, and to end the pretense that it doesn’t matter. Those who are watching him with an open mind have seen a strong performance this year. His State of the Union address on Feb. 7 shattered the Republican attempts to portray him as doddering. With a passion rarely seen at one of these speeches — let alone in his political history — Mr. Biden presented a remarkably effective defense of his presidency and gave a preview of what is likely to be an imminent re-election campaign.

The Times reported last summer that Mr. Biden’s overall energy level has declined, and he continues to stumble over words in his public appearances. But those flaws alone don’t signal a politician who is too old to run again. His first term, in fact, is already full of accomplishment: The economy has added 12.6 million jobs since he took office, inflation is cooling, and he has signed significant legislation to fight climate change, improve access to health care, and make investments in manufacturing and infrastructure. He has stood up to Russia’s destructive campaign in Ukraine, and rallied the West to Ukraine’s side.

Nonetheless, as Mr. Biden nears his actuarial life expectancy, concerns about his ability to handle the demands of campaigning and a potential second term are unlikely to disappear. Only a combination of performance and complete candor will change the minds of skeptical voters. Old age remains a sensitive topic, and many people, particularly men, are reluctant to discuss personal infirmities for fear of demonstrating weakness or being pushed aside by impatient younger generations. There is good reason for the federal government’s prohibition of age discrimination in employment — a protection that begins at age 40. Ageism is real.

That law, however, doesn’t apply to people who are running for office. Voters have every right to ask questions about the medical condition of a candidate who wants their support. In 2016 both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton gave the public very few details about their health. (Mr. Trump released a particularly preposterous doctor’s letter claiming he would be “the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.”)

Mr. Biden acknowledged during the lead-up to the 2020 campaign that he was “chronologically” old but said it was up to voters to decide whether that was important. In that election, against an opponent who was only four years younger, the answer was clearly no. In November 2021, he released a medical report that said he was a “healthy, vigorous 78-year-old” and noted nothing more serious than a stiffened gait due to spinal changes and some acid reflux that caused him to cough.

His most recent health summary, released on Feb. 16, said much the same thing, describing him as a “healthy, vigorous 80-year-old male who is fit to successfully execute the duties of the presidency.” But his cognitive abilities went unmentioned. That’s something he should discuss publicly and also demonstrate to the voters, who expect the president to reflect the nation’s strength.

If he runs again, Mr. Biden will need to provide explicit reassurance to voters; many of them have seen family members decline rapidly in their 80s. Americans are watching what Mr. Biden says and does, just as he has asked them to do.
question: 2. Should candidates for public office be required to disclose their medical conditions to the public?
close_book_answer: In my opinion, candidates for public office should not be required to disclose their medical conditions to the public. There are several reasons why I hold this view.

Firstly, the disclosure of medical conditions can be a personal matter that should be kept private. It is not the business of the public to know about a person's medical history, and it can be stigmatizing for individuals to have their medical conditions made public.

Secondly, the disclosure of medical conditions can be used to discredit or discriminate against a candidate. In some cases, a candidate's medical condition may be used to suggest that they are unfit for public office, which can be a form of discrimination.
Lastly, the disclosure of medical conditions can be a violation of privacy. Candidates have a right to privacy, and the disclosure of their medical conditions can be a breach of that right.

In conclusion, while transparency is important in public office, the disclosure of medical conditions should not be required. It is a personal matter that should be kept private, and the disclosure of medical conditions can be used to discriminate against candidates.
point_form_close_book_answer: 1. Disclosure of medical conditions can be a personal matter that should be kept private.
2. Disclosure of medical conditions can be used to discredit or discriminate against a candidate.
3. Disclosure of medical conditions can be a violation of privacy.
4. Transparency is important in public office, but the disclosure of medical conditions should not be required.
5. Candidates have a right to privacy.
